div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin Feb. 29th 1916
div1.p:
There are so many orders coming through daily that I do not know where I shall end up. First off it was decreed that Americans should be perfectioned at Belleville where Kiffin, Thaw, etc. are at present, and then that all should be perfectioned on Caudrons. Today it has been ordained that Americans should train as well as be perfectioned on Caudrons so as to supply the heavy machines needed for the American escadrille. So far I’ve dodged them and am
going ahead on the Nieufort with which I am doing well. If they try to change me I shall tell them I lied on enlisting and am really French, and if that doesn’t work and they put me on a Caudron I will break one machine after another. Then I will be put in jail and I’ll stay there until I have my way if its five years. Thaw, Cowden, & Prince have been put on Nieuforts and now that they have good machines they are fixing it so we’ll get the needed but rotten ones. I was sent to the Nieufort not because I
was unfortunate enough to be born an American but on account of my record. Having earned the right to an avion de chasse I’m not going to give it up. I’m the only American here that was sent to the Nieufort. By the way I told you didn’t I that I have to wait here before going to the front and do not have the Belleville school to pass? Sorry, as I won’t have much time. I go to Le Bourget where is the General Reserve and then to the front.

I suppose you are working very hard now
on account of the Verdun attack. But please don’t overwork yourself Marcelle.
Mrs. Slade wrote me a very fine letter. I do not see how she could have been so nice about it all. She really was splendid. I will always be grateful to her.

Because some of the officers here got soused and tore up Pau it is forbidden every one of us to go there. I do not know what the men will do who have been in the habit of going there. As for myself I don’t care a rap. Hope to be out soon anyway.
